statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Cardinal feel right at home at Pauley Pavilion
article.linkText: Stanford notches record win at Pauley Pavilion
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Patience proved virtuous again for Stanford. Dan Grunfeld scored 25 points and Stanford defeated UCLA 75-64 Thursday night, giving the Cardinal its eighth consecutive victory at Pauley Pavilion -- the most by an opponent since the building opened 40 years ago. "We put no extra on that," first-year Stanford coach Trent Johnson said. "We knew they had a group of good, talented players and we prepared for that. We came out and wanted to make them work for everything." Stanford (9-7, 3-3 Pac-10) also won its fifth in a row over the Bruins. Last season, the Cardinal clinched its fourth conference title in six years by winning at Pauley. "We've been struggling a little bit, but hopefully this is our turnaround here," Stanford senior Rob Little said. "I've never lost at UCLA. I take pride in this." The Bruins (10-5, 4-3) haven't beaten the Cardinal at home since 1997. They lost their second in a row and first at home in nine games this season. "That was a tough loss against a good team," Bruins coach Ben Howland said. "They played like a team that won 30 games a year ago. They were very, very patient. We played a lot more defense than they did because they had the ball." UCLA got no closer than six points in the second half, the last time when freshman Jordan Farmar scored to make it 50-44 with 9½ minutes remaining. Grunfeld hit a 3-pointer and the Cardinal outscored UCLA 6-2 to push its lead back to double digits. Grunfeld, the son of Washington Wizards general manager Ernie Grunfeld, has improved his scoring average by 14.7 points from last season -- the best by a Division I player this season. He missed tying his career high by four points. "It was a matter of moving the ball around and hitting the open shot in the flow of the game," he said. Matt Haryasz added 14 points, Nick Robinson had 13 and Little 12. Never in a hurry and always willing to wait for a good shot, the Cardinal shot 56 percent in the second half when the Bruins hit at just a 39 percent clip. "We have to stay aggressive from start to finish," Johnson said. "At this level, you have to play a good half-court game." Center Michael Fey led the Bruins with 17 points and 11 rebounds in his best offensive performance of the season. "I got going early and kept it going," he said. UCLA needed him because leading scorer Dijon Thompson had his worst. He was scoreless in the first half and finished with six points on 3-for-11 shooting -- the only time he hasn't reached double figures this season. Thompson also committed six turnovers. "The senior didn't step up," said Thompson, who had two early offensive fouls. "I just came out flat. I wasn't aggressive." The Bruins had scored 80 or more points in three of their previous four games, but never came close against Stanford's defense that held them to 40 percent field-goal shooting for the game. "They slow it down, take good shots, show patience. That's what Stanford is known for," Farmar said.
